awd_titl_txt: STEM-Pros: Growing More STEM Professionals in the Heartland
awd_abstract_narration:
The STEM-Pros project at Upper Iowa University (UIU) will increase recruitment, retention, and degree completion while preparing STEM professionals for the 21st century workplace. STEM-Pros scholars will develop their full potential as STEM professionals by establishing self-identity and acquiring the skills to define and solve complex problems. With faculty guidance, academic supports, co-curricular experiences, and innovative family programming, students will more fully engage in their chosen fields and thus persist in overcoming challenges. STEM-Pros will focus on four majors (environmental science, forensic science, computing sciences/information technology, and mathematics), and will provide support for 14 students over five years. 

Impacts of family-oriented programming on retention, academic achievement, and STEM career trajectories of 14 STEM-Pros scholars will be assessed using a mixed-methods, quasi-experimental study, conducted with an external evaluator. The evaluation will utilize a nonequivalent comparison group with dependent pretest and posttest samples. To reduce selection differences, the treatment group (students that receive family-oriented programming) will be matched with a comparison group (students in the same program and department, but that do not receive family-oriented programming) on characteristics associated with outcomes including gender, GPA, and other factors. Qualitative and quantitative instruments will be used in interviews and online questionnaires of individuals including: (1) two STEM-Pros cohorts and their matched comparison cohorts; (2) local STEM industry partners; (3) family orientation participants and facilitators; and (4) management team.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The STEM-Pros: Growing More STEM Professionals in the Heartland project at Upper Iowa University was intended to increase recruitment, retention, and degree completion while preparing STEM professionals for the 21st century workplace, providing support for 14 S-STEM Scholars over five years. Because some activities and programming were curtailed during the pandemic, ultimately 34 S-STEM Scholars participated in the project.  As of May 2023, 13 have graduated in a STEM major; two (2) declared nonSTEM majors, and therefore left the program, but both successfully graduated. Eight (8) are still pursuing STEM majors. Retention of 62% in STEM was achieved during the project; overall retention was 68%. Students from groups under-represented in STEM disciplines made up 38% of S-STEM Scholars, exceeding the percentage of URM students in the university student body as a whole. 

Desired outcomes for STEM-Pros scholars included developing their full potential as STEM professionals by establishing self-identity and acquiring the skills to define and solve complex problems. Strategies included intensive faculty mentoring, academic supports, co-curricular experiences, and innovative family programming. STEM-Pros originally focused on four majors (environmental science, forensic science, computing sciences/information technology, and mathematics).  We successfully recruited two student cohorts (Fall 2017 and Fall 2018) and conducted family programming, first-year seminars, and other scholar supports. In February 2019, the S-STEM Scholars and other interested students participated in the AAAS National Meeting in Washington, DC.  This intensive experience completely transformed participant views on the importance of STEM disciplines and their own ability to contribute as STEM professionals to positive change in the world.  Participation also stimulated cohesiveness among the cohorts and other participating STEM students.

Initially, we planned to assess the impacts of family-oriented programming on retention, academic achievement, and STEM career trajectories of the STEM-Pros Scholars using a mixed-methods, quasi-experimental study with our external evaluator. Continuing and persistent challenges in recruiting and enrollment resulted in small numbers of students enrolled in STEM majors, and it was not possible to identify a comparison group, nor to complete the study as originally planned. 

Over the course of the grant period, institutional support for the target majors dwindled to the point where three of the original four majors were eliminated by the university in December 2020.  In consultation with our program officer at the time, we expanded the eligible majors for the project to include biology, and recruited additional academically talented STEM students with unmet financial need as S-STEM Scholars to complete the project. 

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2024
Modified by: Katherine A Mccarville
